__data__.text:
- Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) established chapters in Anchorage and Fairbanks, Alaska in December 1982 after merging with the Brothers MC.
- The Brothers MC had an association with the Hells Angels in California's San Francisco Bay Area by 1977.
- Alaskan Hells Angels involved in methamphetamine trafficking.
- Anthony John Tait, Anchorage Hells Angels chapter sergeant-at-arms, became a paid informant for the FBI in 1985 and provided information on the club's criminal activities for two years.
- Operation CACUS: FBI and Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) agents arrested 38 HAMC members in Alaska and four other states on narcotics, weapons, explosives and conspiracy charges on November 10, 1987.
- Anchorage chapter president Edward Floyd Hubert and Fairbanks chapter president Dennis E. Pailing among those arrested.
- Ten Hells Angels from California and Alaska, including Hubert and Pailing, charged with conspiring to transport firearms and explosives across state lines to kill Outlaws members in retaliation for the death of John Cleave Webb.
- Hubert, Lawrence Russell Hagel and Gerald G. Protzman convicted of misdemeanor charge of converting a government intelligence manual for their use in October 1988; Pailing and four other Alaskan Angels acquitted.
- Four Alaskan Hells Angels arrested on federal racketeering and firearms charges in December 2003.
- Hells Angels allegedly put a $1 million bounty on Tait's life.
- Hells Angels member James William Leffel convicted of first-degree assault for stabbing a man in 2002.
- Michael "Steak Knife" Staton kidnapped, tortured and killed by 1488s gang members in 2017 after being accused of stealing drugs and "colors" from Craig "Oakie" King, a Hells Angels member and 1488s associate.
- King and five 1488s members arrested and charged with murder, kidnapping

- Hells Angels member James William Leffel convicted of first-degree assault for stabbing a man named Jens Schurig outside a bar in Anchorage in 2017.
- Michael "Steak Knife" Staton was kidnapped, tortured, and killed by white supremacist prison gang 1488s in 2017 after being accused of stealing drugs and "colors" from Hells Angels member Craig "Oakie" King.
- King and five 1488s members arrested in 2019, charged with murder, kidnapping, and racketeering crimes including drug trafficking. King convicted of racketeering conspiracy, murder, kidnapping, and sentenced to life in prison in 2023.
- Hells Angels members Charles Denver "Pup" Phillips and Lois Latrilla Phillips arrested in Anchorage in 2018 for distributing and conspiring to distribute methamphetamine. Charles Phillips sentenced to 18 years in federal prison, Lois Phillips sentenced to 5 years.
- Arizona Hells Angels produce and distribute methamphetamine, classified as a criminal street gang by Arizona Department of Public Safety. Established six Arizona chapters after merging with Dirty Dozen in 1997.
- Greg "Snake" Surdukan and Chris "Porker" Baucum, president and vice-president of Arizona Hells Angels nomads chapter, arrested in 2001 for narcotics trafficking after DEA uncovered international drug network involving smuggling of methamphetamine from South Africa. Surdukan sentenced to 15 years' imprisonment.
- Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) initiated undercover investigation "Operation Black Biscuit" in 2001, resulting in 21-month infiltration of the club by ATF agents, technicians, and confidential informants. ATF used fabricated story of arming Solo Angeles in Mexico to combat Mongols chapter to make contact with Hells Angels and form Solo Angeles nomads chapter in Arizona.

* Operation Black Biscuit was a 21-month investigation by the ATF into the Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) in Arizona
 	+ ATF agents, technicians, and confidential informants infiltrated the club
	+ Methamphetamine and firearm dealer Kramer collaborated with HAMC in narcotics and weapons smuggling
	+ Kramer sought permission to form a Solo Angeles nomads chapter in Arizona, which the ATF used to make contact with the Hells Angels
	+ Undercover ATF agent Jay Dobyns staged the murder of a Mongols member to gain the Hells Angels' trust
	+ Dobyns was allegedly voted in as a member of the Hells Angels' Skull Valley chapter, but this is denied by the HAMC
* The operation ended prematurely due to a plot to murder the Solo Angeles, who were believed to be a potential rival encroaching on Hells Angels' territory
* Synchronized raids across Arizona resulted in the arrests of 52 people and the seizure of over 500 illegal weapons, ammunition, $50,000 in cash, and drugs
* Club prospect Michael Wayne Coffelt was shot and wounded by police officer Laura Beeler during a raid; charges against Coffelt were dismissed
* The investigation was deemed a success by the ATF, but internal government disagreement led to half of the defendants plea bargaining to lesser offenses and five others having federal charges dismissed
* In 2004, Mora was convicted of possessing body armor with intent to sell and sentenced to 18 months in prison, but the conviction was overturned the following year after an appeal
* The Skull Valley chapter disbanded as a result of the investigation
* In October 2001, Hells Angels members Kevin J. Augustiniak, Michael Christopher "Mesa Mike" Kramer, and Paul Merle Eischeid murdered Cynthia Yvonne Garcia, a 44-year-old mother of six, who verbally disrespected the club and its members while in an intoxicated state during a party at the Hells Angels' clubhouse in Mesa
	+ Garcia was beaten unconscious, loaded into the trunk of a car

- In 2001, Cynthia Garcia was murdered by Hells Angels members Kevin J. Augustiniak, Michael Christopher "Mesa Mike" Kramer, and Paul Merle Eischeid due to verbal disrespect towards the club.
- Garcia was beaten, stabbed 27 times, and attempted to be decapitated. Her body was found in the desert near the Salt River on October 31, 2001.
- Michael Christopher "Mesa Mike" Kramer became an informant for the ATF and offered information on Garcia's killing in exchange for immunity from prosecution. He served five years of probation for the murder.
- Paul Merle Eischeid fled the country following his indictment for the killing in 2007 and was placed on the USMS 15 Most Wanted Fugitives list. He was apprehended in Argentina on February 3, 2011, and extradited to Arizona in July 2018.
- Kevin J. Augustiniak pleaded guilty to second-degree murder in October 2011 and was sentenced to 23 years and 6 months' imprisonment in March 2012.
- Joshua William Harber, a member of the Hells Angels chapter in Ventura, California, was shot in the face outside a bar in Cave Creek on June 8, 2002, and died later that day. The crime has become a cold case.
- Daniel Leroy "Hoover" Seybert, president of the Cave Creek Hells Angels chapter, was shot to death outside a bar in Phoenix on March 22, 2003. The homicide has never been solved.
- Seven Hells Angels members were arrested in Arizona on various charges on December 3, 2003, following a two-year investigation by the ATF.
- Two Arizona Angels, Rodney Cox and Calvin Schaefer, were among six HAMC members convicted in a case after being extradited to Las Vegas, Nevada to stand trial.
- Patrick Michael Eberhardt, treasurer of the Hells Angels' Cave Creek chapter, was shot dead and a club hangaround was wounded in Phoenix on February 7,

- Rodney Cox and Calvin Schaefer, Arizona Angels members, were convicted in a case in Las Vegas, Nevada in 2007. Cox was sentenced to 2 years in prison and Schaefer to 4 years and 3 months for committing a violent crime in the aid of racketeering.
- Patrick Michael Eberhardt, treasurer of the Hells Angels' Cave Creek chapter, was shot and killed in Phoenix on February 7, 2015. A club hangaround was also wounded. A Mongols member is a suspect in Eberhardt's unsolved murder.
- Wayne Whitt, a Hells Angels Mesa chapter member, shot and killed a Mongols member and wounded another in Tempe on August 17, 2016. The shooting followed a verbal altercation inside a sports bar. Whitt was not charged as the shooting was deemed self-defense.
- Five Hells Angels and two members of the Desert Road Riders were arrested in Mohave County in December 2009 as part of Operation Quiet Riot, a six-month investigation into a turf war involving the Hells Angels, Desert Road Riders and Vagos.
- Four Hells Angels members were acquitted of rioting and assisting in a criminal street gang in Bullhead City on June 11, 2009. Another member took a plea deal and was sentenced to 2.5 years in prison.
- Members of the Hells Angels were allegedly involved in a shoot-out with Vagos members in Chino Valley on August 21, 2010. Over fifty shots were fired and at least five people were wounded. Charges against seven Hells Angels members were dismissed in June 2012.
- Nathaniel Barton Sample, a Hells Angels member, was convicted in September 2009 of aggravated assault and acting for the benefit of a street gang following an incident at a Scottsdale bar.
- William Gary "Tramp" Potter, former Tucson Hells Angels chapter president, was arrested in July 2010 for the murder of Randall Scott Pfeil. He pleaded guilty in April 2012 to second-degree murder and was

- Pfeil was a missing person who was found shot twice in the head. Potter pleaded guilty to second-degree murder and weapons charges, and was sentenced to 19 years in prison.
- Bruce Schweigert, Sr., treasurer of the Yavapai County chapter of the Hells Angels, was sentenced to 8 years in prison for threatening and intimidating as a criminal street gang member, assault, disorderly conduct, and weapons misconduct. The charges stem from a bar fight in Cottonwood, Arizona in 2013.
- The Hells Angels are the most significant motorcycle gang in California in terms of membership and criminal activity, with over 300 members statewide. They are involved in methamphetamine distribution and other illegal enterprises, and have a significant role in the infiltration of legitimate businesses.
- The Hells Angels have three chapters in Colorado, with the first one being initiated in 2001 by amalgamating the Brothers Fast MC. They expanded into the state at a time when the Sons of Silence, historically the state's preeminent motorcycle gang, were weakened by a federal investigation.
- In August 1996, two members of the Hells Angels' San Fernando Valley, California chapter were shot and wounded at the Iron Horse Inn in Steamboat Springs, Colorado. The shooting was believed to be a punishment for a breach of club rules.
- In November 2005, a group of Hells Angels were allegedly involved in a bar fight with other patrons at the Black Nugget Saloon in Carbondale, Colorado.
- John Lockhart, a prospective member of the Hells Angels' LaSalle-based Colorado nomads chapter, was charged with attempted first-degree murder, vehicular eluding, and illegal discharge of a firearm in June 2017. He was convicted of vehicular eluding in March 2019 and acquitted of attempted first-degree murder and illegal discharge of a firearm. A mistrial was declared on the charge of attempted first-degree murder of a peace officer, but he was subsequently convicted in a retrial in June 2019.

- On June 11, 2019, Lockhart shot at a SUV and a police cruiser in a road rage incident near Colorado State Highway 60 in Milliken. He was identified by surveillance video and was previously convicted of vehicular eluding and acquitted of attempted first-degree murder.
- In July 2020, a gun battle between Hells Angels and Mongols members occurred in the parking lot of Jake's Roadhouse bar and restaurant in Arvada, leaving one Hells Angels member dead and three others injured.
- In July 2001, the Denver Police Department (DPD) raided the Hells Angels' clubhouse in the Highlands neighborhood and three club members were arrested. In 2003, a federal lawsuit was filed against DPD alleging illegal search and violation of constitutional rights, resulting in a $50,000 settlement.
- In September 2005, Hells Angels members Shiloh Frazier and Todd Zahn were arrested for possession of handguns after being pulled over for speeding in Denver. Frazier's charges were dismissed and Zahn pleaded guilty to possession of weapon by a previous offender.
- In August 2007, the Hells Angels filed a federal lawsuit against Denver and Mountain View police departments for an unconstitutional traffic stop and search without probable cause, resulting in a $14,000 settlement in January 2008.
- In April 2020, HAMC member Anthony Mills filed a federal lawsuit against the city of Greeley, the town of LaSalle and the Weld County Sheriff's Office, as well as individual officers from those jurisdictions and from the Kersey and Garden City police departments in response to a 2018 incident involving a LaSalle police officer joking about shooting Mills. In September 2020, five police agencies paid $25,000 to Mills to settle the lawsuit.
- In November 2021, Denver Hells Angels chapter member Dustin "Dusty" Ullerich filed a federal lawsuit against Jefferson County, the cities of Golden, Aurora and Arvada, and sixteen individual police officers from four departments over injuries he suffered during a no-knock warrant execution in 20

- In September 2020, five police agencies paid $25,000 to Mills to settle a lawsuit. Mills received an apology and resigned from the police department.
- Dustin "Dusty" Ullerich filed a federal lawsuit in November 2021 against several police departments and officers due to injuries suffered from a no-knock warrant.
- On November 7, 2019, a no-knock warrant was executed at Ullerich's home, and he was hospitalized after being hit by a projectile from a shotgun discharged by Deputy Anthony Brown.
- Brown was cleared of wrongdoing in 2020.
- The operation targeted fourteen bikers in an organized crime case, resulting in the indictment of thirteen Hells Angels members and one Destroyers gang member.
- The five-month investigation began in July 2019 after former HAMC member Joshua O'Bryan offered details on the Denver chapter's alleged involvement in various crimes.
- O'Bryan survived an ambush and was beaten and kidnapped by Hells Angels in separate incidents.
- One defendant, William "Kelly" Henderson, was killed in a shootout before standing trial, and charges were dismissed against Michael Dire.
- Connecticut has three HAMC chapters, with the Bridgeport chapter being the first established in 1975.
- Connecticut Hells Angels have been recruited as enforcers and contract killers for the Mafia.
- In 1975, Officer John McGee was attacked and beaten by Hells Angels members after issuing a speeding citation.
- In May 1975, five Bridgeport Hells Angels members were arrested for first-degree manslaughter in connection with the death of José Sosa.
- In July 1975, Frank D'Amato and Salvatore Saffioti were killed, and Donald "Big Red" Meredith was wounded by Donald E. Krosky after forcing their way into a hotel and bar.

- Sosa, a Hells Angels member, died from multiple head and internal injuries on July 31, 1975. His body was found in the back of his parked car by three passing youths the following afternoon. Three other Hells Angels were later apprehended on the same charges.
- Frank D'Amato and Salvatore Saffioti, Hells Angels members, were killed and Donald "Big Red" Meredith was left wounded in critical condition after being shot with a .44 Magnum carbine by Donald E. Krosky on July 31, 1975.
- Krosky was charged with two counts of murder and one count of assault with intent to murder on November 10, 1975, but was freed on a $100,000 bail bond. He was later shot dead with a shotgun on July 20, 1976.
- Frank Passalaqua was investigated for the homicide of Alfred Chisholm, a black inmate who was strangled to death at Northern Correctional Institution on November 10, 1977.
- Daniel Eugene "Diamond Dan" Bifield, president of the Bridgeport Hells Angels chapter, was arrested for possession of a shotgun by a convicted felon in October 1980 and was sentenced to two years in prison on November 20, 1980.
- Joseph Whelan fatally stabbed bar patron John Matulionis after a verbal altercation in a Bridgeport barroom on February 24, 1980, and was sentenced to twenty-five-years-to-life in prison for the murder.
- Daniel "Dan" Klimas, sergeant-at-arms of the Hells Angels, shot and killed Todd Festa, a rejected club prospect and state police informant, in Wallingford on January 7, 1998. Klimas pleaded guilty to murder and possession of a pistol without a permit, and was sentenced to twenty-eight years in prison on March 3, 2000.
- Roger Mariani, a senior member of the Hells Angels in Connecticut, was shot and killed while riding his motorcycle on the Connecticut Turnpi

- In late December 2015, Howard Hammer, an associate of loanshark James Broderick III, was contracted to collect a $1,500 loan from a delinquent debtor.
- The debtor was stabbed eight times, beaten with a hammer, and blinded in one eye in a New Milford hotel room on January 25, 2016, after falsely claiming to be the acting president of the New York Hells Angels chapter.
- Hammer and Broderick were arrested on May 27, 2016, but Hammer refused to identify those involved in the assault.
- An investigation revealed that members of the Hells Angels' Bridgeport chapter had attacked the victim in connection with the extortion scheme.
- Hammer pleaded guilty to conspiracy to participate in the collection and attempted collection of an extension of credit by extortionate means on December 2, 2016, and was sentenced to two-and-a-half years' imprisonment on June 1, 2017.
- Broderick pleaded guilty to the same charge on December 7, 2016, and was sentenced to two years' on June 29, 2017.
- In August 1981, Daniel Bifield and two Bridgeport Hells Angels associates were convicted of conspiring to make and collect extortionate loans, and Hobbs Act violations for their involvement in a loansharking operation headed by Francis "Fat Franny" Curcio.
- Bifield and three others escaped from the Bridgeport Correctional Center on September 23, 1981, and Bifield became the subject of an international manhunt by the FBI.
- Bifield was sentenced to two consecutive twenty-year prison sentences on the extortion charge and an additional five years' imprisonment for escape from the custody of the United States Attorney General.
- Thirty-seven members and associates of the Bridgeport Hells Angels were arrested on racketeering and drug trafficking charges on May 2, 1985, in connection with a three-year FBI investigation known as Operation Roughrider.
- The investigation involved around a thousand law enforcement personnel and resulted in the arrests of a total of 1

- In 1980, 35 members of HAMC were charged and convicted, including Roger "Bear" Mariani, Robert "Red Dog" Redmann, and Joseph Whelan, who received 15-year sentences. Robert Banning became a cooperating witness.
- In 1986, detective Nicholas Barone and H. James Pickerstein received intelligence about planned attacks by HAMC due to their involvement in investigations and prosecutions. Barone received extended security as a result.
- In 2005, four leading HAMC members in northern Illinois were arrested and charged with crimes including violating the RICO Act. Melvin "Road" Chancey, David G. "Pulley" Ohlendorf, and Richard A. Abrams were sentenced to 9, 4, and 3 years in prison, respectively.
- Their group was involved in criminal activities such as the 1994 shooting of a rival club president, threats to bomb a rival gang's clubhouse, and planning two murders to protect drug sales (cocaine and methamphetamine) worth $624,000 from 1993 to 2002.
- In 2016, law enforcement faced backlash for heavily patrolling a HAMC charity event in Indiana, which attracted about 80 motorcycles. Authorities summoned the Chicago area's SWAT team and helicopter unit, causing public dissatisfaction.
- In October 1988, Ralph "Sonny" Barger and Michael Vincent "Irish" O'Farrell were convicted of plotting bomb attacks in Louisville against members of the Outlaws in revenge for the murder of a Hells Angels member.
- In May 2002, Pagans member Christopher J. Brennan shot and wounded three Hells Angels in Maryland. He pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment and served 90 days in jail.
- In July 2003, four members of the North Beach Hells Angels chapter were indicted on federal drug and firearm charges. John Anthony Beal, Lewis James Hall, Cornelius Wood Alexander, and Traecy Eugenia Hall were arrested, and 17 firearms, over 270 rounds of

- Brennan pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment in Nov. 2002, after prosecutors dropped attempted murder charges due to lack of witness cooperation.
- In Jul. 2003, four members of the North Beach Hells Angels chapter were arrested by the ATF on federal drug and firearm charges.
  - Weapons, ammunition, a bulletproof vest, and methamphetamine were uncovered during raids.
  - Two undercover ATF agents witnessed Beal sell cocaine to Warlocks members at the Hells Angels' clubhouse.
- The Hells Angels have established chapters in Lowell, Lynn, Salem, Cape Cod, and Berkshire County, with the Lowell chapter being the first on the East Coast (founded in 1966).
- The Hells Angels are significant in drug trafficking in Massachusetts and have collaborated with the Boston faction of the Patriarca crime family in loansharking and narcotics distribution.
- In Dec. 1969, Hells Angels were involved in a battle with police in Lowell, resulting in five officers being injured and several weapons being seized.
- In Aug. 1975, Hells Angels members Hogan, LaRocque, and Quartarone, Jr. kidnapped and severely beat Theodore Condon, receiving convictions for kidnapping, assault, and mayhem.
- In Sep. 1984, Salem Hells Angels member Leary was arrested for operating under the influence and assault and battery charges after an incident at a Peabody police station.
- In 1997, two Hells Angels were accused of raping a woman at the Lynn chapter's clubhouse during Alan Hogan's funeral.
- In Nov. 2004, Salem Hells Angels members Costin and Duda were charged with assault and battery following an attack on off-duty police lieutenant Coleman in a Lynn bar.

- Leary, a Hells Angels member, was charged with assault and battery and making threats, but was acquitted.
- Two Hells Angels were accused of raping a woman at the Lynn chapter's clubhouse, but specific outcomes are not mentioned.
- Costin and Duda, Hells Angels members, were charged with assault and battery after attacking an off-duty police lieutenant. Costin was sentenced to two-to-four years in prison.
- Ranieri, a Hells Angels member, was arrested for assaulting a police officer and given a ninety-day suspended sentence.
- Franco, the sergeant-at-arms of the Lynn Hells Angels chapter, was convicted of possessing a firearm and ammunition after assaulting his girlfriend. He was sentenced to twenty-one years in prison.
- Eliason and Barr, members of the Hells Angels' Salem chapter, along with other members from both the Hells Angels and the Red Devils, were arrested for kidnapping, mayhem, and extortion. They were sentenced to eight and four years in prison.
- Urban, a Hells Angels member, was fatally shot in the heart in 1974 in an unsolved murder. Veherbon, another Hells Angels member, was wounded in the same incident. The shooting may have been related to a conflict with a rival club, Lucifer's Henchmen MC.

- Conflict between Hells Angels MC (HAMC) and Lucifer's Henchmen MC over a café incident on April 7, 1975, where Thomas Abernathy Jr. was allegedly stabbed by two HAMC members.
- HAMC reportedly won the feud, seizing colors of ten or eleven Lucifer's Henchmen members, and three rival bikers fled the state.
- "Whiskey" George Hartman Jr., charged with the non-fatal stabbing, was murdered in Florida on April 30, 1975, before trial.
- A man sentenced in the café assault was released from prison days before Abernathy Jr.'s nail bomb injury on March 24, 1975.
- James Rich was stabbed by four unidentified men outside a bar in Revere Beach on September 20, 1981, believed to be Hells Angels members.
- Rich's friends, Robert L. Cobb, Arthur A. Corbett, and Andrew J. Millyan, sought revenge and murdered Dana Hill on September 21, 1981.
- Cobb, Corbett, and Millyan were arrested and indicted on first-degree murder charges, convicted, and sentenced to life in prison.
- Two Hells Angels members were stabbed in Revere on November 8, 1991, allegedly by Devil's Disciples members.
- Michael J. Blair and Jake Doherty were arrested in 2016 for beating two Defiant Disciples MC members with a flashlight.
- Seven bikers were stabbed during a brawl between Hells Angels and Pagans in front of the Pagans' Fall River clubhouse on May 14, 2022.
- Michele Gagnon, a Hells Angels member, is a prime suspect in two unsolved murders in Lynn in 1979.
- Gagnon's girlfriend, Susan Marie DeQuina, went missing on October 3, 1979, and her car was found abandoned and burned in Saugus.
- Robert "Bino" Garbino, Gagnon's roommate, was found

- Vincent "Jimmy" Garbino, a member of the Hells Angels, was found murdered in his Lynn residence in 1979. His severed head and hands were buried in the yard. He was suspected to have been killed by the Hells Angels over a drug rip-off.
- Garbino's suspected killer, William "Billy" Gagnon, was found shot to death in Bridgeport, Connecticut. His death was ruled a suicide, but some authorities believe he did not take his own life.
- Hells Angels members Alan J. Cutler, Edward R. Simard, and John L. Burke were arrested in connection with the murder of Vincent DeNino, a drug dealer, in 1986. DeNino was allegedly killed over a $10,000 debt from a cocaine deal.
- Trampers MC member Darin F. "Nino" Bufalino was also arrested in connection with DeNino's murder. He fled to Ireland and Spain before being apprehended.
- Charges against Cutler, Simard, Burke, and Bufalino were dismissed in 1990 due to inadmissible FBI wiretap evidence.
- Adam Lee Hall, Caius Veiovis, and David Chalue, members of the Hells Angels' Berkshire County chapter, were convicted of murdering Robert Chadwell, Edward Frampton, and David Glasser in 2014. The victims were dismembered with an electric circular saw.
- Alan Hogan, Robert Montgomery, and Thomas Apostolos, members of the Hells Angels, were imprisoned after police discovered a methamphetamine lab in Middleton in 1980.
- Five Hells Angels members were arrested in the Greater Boston area in 1985 on charges of conspiracy to distribute cocaine. The three-year investigation, Operation Roughrider, resulted in 133 Hells Angels members and associates being indicted on drug trafficking and racketeering charges.
- Thirteen members and former members of the Lowell Hells Angels were indicted in 1991 on charges of conspiracy to distribute methamphetamine as part of a drug ring that operated in Massachusetts and New Hampshire between 19

- In September 1991, thirteen members and former members of the Lowell Hells Angels were indicted on charges of conspiracy to distribute methamphetamine as part of a drug ring in Massachusetts and New Hampshire (1987-1991).
- Glenn "Hoppy" Main and Steve "Fee" Sullivan were sentenced to three years in prison, while Linwood "Lee" Barrett III was acquitted.
- Frank Briggs and Julio "Jules" Lucido of the Berkshire County chapter received one and four years in prison, respectively.
- Charles T. "Doc" Pasciuti and fourteen others were sentenced in January 1993 after pleading guilty to possession with intent to distribute methamphetamine, and conspiracy.
- Sentences ranged from fifteen years' imprisonment for Pasciuti to three years' probation.
- Several government witnesses entered the Federal Witness Protection Program, including Crazy Eights MC president Gaylen Blake, Crazy Eights associates David and Larry Machado, Die Hards MC president Gordon Tardiff, and HAMC associate Robin Golden.
- The DEA began an investigation of the Salem Hells Angels chapter in February 1995, resulting in the arrests of sixteen members and associates in September 1996.
- Gregory "Greg" Domey, the chapter president, was sentenced to twenty years' imprisonment in 1997 after pleading guilty to running a criminal enterprise that sold cocaine and methamphetamine.
- John R. "Johnny Bart" Bartolomeo pleaded guilty to possession with intent to distribute, and conspiracy to distribute, cocaine and methamphetamine in May 1998 and was sentenced to thirty-five years.
- Two Hells Angels members, a prospect, and an associate were arrested on firearms charges in March 1986 as part of Operation One Percenter.
- George Harvey of Revere and Peter Lazarus Jr. of Lynn were convicted; Harvey was sentenced to serve a year in prison at FCI Danbury, while Lazarus was sentenced to probation.
- The Hells Angels took over ancillary activities of the Patriarca crime family's Boston faction, such as loansharking and drug

- In 1987, Mark "Rebel" McKenna and eleven other Hells Angels members were indicted for operating a large loansharking ring in Boston, collecting $3.5 million from 350 victims.
- In 2007, a joint investigation by the ATF, DEA, MSP, and IRS led to the arrest of six Hells Angels members in Boston for various charges.
- In April 2022, a shooting occurred at the Hells Angels clubhouse in Springfield, Missouri, resulting in one member being shot. Video recordings were recovered, and the victim warned police to catch the shooters before the Angels do to prevent retaliation.
- The first Hells Angels chapter outside California was established in Omaha, Nebraska, in 1966. They have been involved in methamphetamine distribution and violent incidents in the state.
- In 1967, eleven members were arrested for disorderly conduct at a party, and in 1969, a group was involved in a brawl with police at a bar, leading to the conviction of one member for assault with a can opener.
- In 1971, Louis Lundholm was charged with assault after attacking a man with a baseball bat and pushing a man in a wheelchair down stairs.
- In 1972, the home of a liquor commission inspector was bombed, and Hells Angels member Roger Levell was suspected but not charged due to insufficient evidence.
- In 1973, two bodies found west of the Elkhorn River were suspected to be Hells Angels members killed by blunt force trauma and gunshot wounds.
- In 1980, Leslie Fitzgerald was shot and killed during a fight outside a Hells Angels party, with the acquittal of his killer due to self-defense.
- In 2013, Jay Witt was sentenced to 30-40 years in prison for manslaughter in the shooting of Hells Angels member William "Willy" John Furlong. Witt died in prison in 2019.
- In 1968, Orval Hinz, Ronald Eugene Kirby, and Robert Walker were charged with first-degree

- Witt died at Nebraska State Penitentiary on September 25, 2019, aged 53, after being charged with first-degree murder.
- Hells Angels members Orval Hinz, Ronald Eugene Kirby, and Robert Walker were charged with first-degree murder of Gilbert Arthur Batten, Jr. in 1968.
- Kirby was convicted of Batten's murder and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- Hells Angels member Thomas Edward "Red" Nesbitt killed Mary Kay Harmer in 1975, and her body was found in April 1984.
- Nesbitt was arrested for Harmer's murder and for conspiracy to manufacture methamphetamine in October 1984.
- Nesbitt was convicted of murder in the first degree on March 7, 1986, and sentenced to life imprisonment.
- The Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs (BNDD) set up a front operation dealing in narcotics, gambling, and pornography in Omaha in December 1969.
- Minneapolis Hells Angels member Steven Paul Liley obtained heroin from Roger Curtis Levell and Dale Ray "Corky" Haley in Omaha on April 21, 1970.
- Haley and Levell sold two ounces of heroin to special agent James McDowell on September 15, 1970.
- Haley, Levell, and Smith were arrested on October 15, 1970, as part of a federal operation.
- Ten members and associates of the Omaha Hells Angels were indicted on February 18, 1981, for their role in a conspiracy to establish a monopoly of the methamphetamine trade in the Omaha area.
- The conspiracy began in December 1972 and is suspected in the unsolved murder of Joseph Sackett in August 1979.
- An eighteen-month investigation culminated in a series of raids on February 28, 1981, resulting in six arrests and the recovery of narcotics and weapons.

- Hells Angels' drug conspiracy in Omaha began in Dec. 1972, suspected in the unsolved murder of Joseph Sackett in 1979.
- An 18-month investigation led to raids in Feb. 1981, resulting in the conviction of 5 individuals for firearms violations and drug possession.
- Omaha Police Department and FBI's Operation Zookeeper targeted a cocaine distribution network; 43 individuals were indicted in 1983, with many being Hells Angels members.
- Operation Roughrider, a 3-year FBI investigation, led to the indictment of 133 Hells Angels members and associates in 1985 on narcotics trafficking and racketeering charges.
- A two-year investigation in 1990 resulted in the arrest of 15 Hells Angels members and associates for racketeering, money laundering, and drug-related charges.
- The River Run Riot in Laughlin, Nevada, in 2002 involved a fight between Hells Angels and Mongols members, leading to the death of members from both groups.
- In 2007, Hells Angels members James Hannigan and Rodney Cox were sentenced to two years in prison for their role in the casino fight.

Notes:

- Drug conspiracy (Omaha, Dec. 1972):
	+ Linked to unsolved murder of Joseph Sackett (Aug. 1979)
	+ Investigation (18 months)
	+ Raids (Feb. 1981): 10 Omaha locations, 1 Council Bluffs, IA location, 1 Santa Rosa, CA location
	+ 6 arrests, seizure of firearms and narcotics
	+ Conviction (Nov. 1981): Gary D. Apker, James "Jim Bob" Cronin, Calvin Davenport, Raymond "Buzzard" Gearhart, Janice Fitzgerald

- Operation Zookeeper (Omaha, 1982-1983):
	+ OPD and FBI targeted cocaine distribution network
	+ 4

- In 2007, Hells Angels members James Hannigan and Rodney Cox were sentenced to two years in prison for their involvement in a brawl with Mongols members at a casino in Clark County, Nevada.
- The brawl was captured on security cameras, showing a Hells Angel performing a front kick on a Mongol biker, but prior to this altercation, there were incidents of harassment and provocation from the Mongols towards the Hells Angels.
- In 1969, 11 members of the Hells Angels' Lowell, Massachusetts chapter were arrested on narcotics-related charges in Nashua, New Hampshire. Chapter president Donald James "Skeets" Picard was convicted on two counts of heroin trafficking and sentenced to two concurrent twenty-year prison sentences.
- In 1972, Hells Angels members Robert Gardner and Kevin Gilroy were shot by Dean Dayutis, a member of the Devil's Disciples Motorcycle Club, while riding their motorcycles in Londonderry. Dayutis was convicted of second-degree murder in 1983 and sentenced to eighteen-to-forty years of imprisonment.
- The Hells Angels formed their first chapter in New Hampshire in March 2000 when members from Massachusetts and Maine established a branch in Manchester.
- In 2010, an innocent bystander was wounded during a fight involving the Hells Angels, Outlaws, and Milford and Company Motorcycle Club outside a restaurant in Manchester.
- In 2017, Hells Angels member James Cunningham was arrested on federal drug trafficking charges and sentenced to three years and three months in prison.
- In the 1970s, the Hells Angels carried out a grenade attack on the home of the Breed's national president in Plainfield, New Jersey.
- In 1983, two members of the Binghamton, New York Hells Angels chapter were charged with assault and attempted murder after a shootout with the New Jersey State Police in Hope Township.
- The Hells Angels established a presence in New Jersey in 2002 with the founding of a prospect chapter in Newark, which was sponsored by the HAMC chapters in New Rochelle

- The Newark chapter of Hells Angels was formed in 2002, following a treaty with the Pagans. They are small but backed by the New York City chapter.
- In 2005, three Hells Angels were beaten by Pagans outside a bar in Woodland Township, allegedly prompting the Hells Angels' East Coast leader to declare war.
- In 2015, four Hells Angels members were indicted for unlawful possession of weapons, prohibited weapon, certain persons not to possess a weapon, and unlawful possession of a controlled dangerous substance.
- The Hells Angels have links with New York's Gambino and Genovese crime families, according to the US Department of Justice.
- In 1971, eight Hells Angels members were arrested for the gang rape of a 17-year-old girl in East Village, Manhattan.
- In 1975, Bruce Meyer was shot five times in the head in retaliation for killing a Hells Angels member in a car crash.
- In 1994, there was a clash between the Hells Angels and a rival biker gang near Buffalo, resulting in two deaths and multiple injuries.
- In 2007, Roberta Shalaby was found beaten outside the Hells Angels' clubhouse in East Village, Manhattan. The NYPD's investigation was criticized by the group, and they intended to sue the city for false arrest and possible civil rights violations.
- A methamphetamine trafficking network run by members and associates of the Hells Angels' Rochester chapter was dismantled in Western New York from 2002 through July 9, 2010.

- Hells Angels Motorcycle Club (HAMC) members and associates in New York were involved in a methamphetamine trafficking network from 2002 to 2010.
 	+ James Henry McAuley, Jr., vice-president of the Rochester chapter, led the drug ring and was sentenced to 25 years in prison in 2016.
 	+ Richard W. Mar, former president of the Monterey (California) chapter, supplied methamphetamine to the Rochester Hells Angels and was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison in 2016.
 	+ Richard E. Riedman, Jeffrey A. Tyler, Donna Boon, Gordon Montgomery, and Paul Griffin pleaded guilty to drug trafficking offenses.
- The first Hells Angels chapter in North Carolina was founded in Durham on July 24, 1973.
- Charlotte chapter was chartered on October 19, 1978, by Michael Franklin "Thunder" Finazzo, a member of the "Filthy Few" from Omaha, Nebraska.
- Under Finazzo's leadership, the Hells Angels took control of much of the city's criminal rackets and operated drug, prostitution, and motorcycle theft rings throughout the state.
- During the Hells Angels' international rally at Kerr Lake on July 4, 1981, journalists from The Charlotte Observer were assaulted by club members.
- Finazzo and his lieutenant Tyler Duris "Yank" Frndak were found shot dead in Randolph County on September 26, 1981.
- Finazzo's successor as chapter president, Fred Martin Scarnechia, and Hells Angel Thomas Lee Campbell assaulted a federal agent during a drug deal sting operation in Fort Mill, South Carolina on July 27, 1982.
- Authorities found a booby-trapped stockpile of weapons in a nearby Rock Hill, South Carolina storage unit, requiring the ATF and an explosive ordnance disposal unit to disarm the trap.
- Scarnechia and Campbell were sentenced to five years in prison for assaulting the federal agent on January 6, 198

- Finazzo's successor as chapter president, Fred Martin Scarnechia, and another Hells Angel, Thomas Lee Campbell, assaulted undercover DEA agent John Landrum in Fort Mill, South Carolina on July 27, 1982.
- Authorities found a booby-trapped stockpile of weapons in a storage unit in Rock Hill, South Carolina, including C-4 explosive, grenades, ammunition, and two submachine guns equipped with silencers.
- Scarnechia and Campbell were sentenced to five years in prison for assaulting the federal agent on January 6, 1983.
- The Charlotte chapter of the Hells Angels was disbanded after the murders of Finazzo and Frndak, and the imprisonment of Scarnechia.
- The clubhouse, known as "the Bunker", was burned down in a suspected arson attack on August 12, 1985.
- The Hells Angels have been involved in contract killings and drug trafficking with the Cleveland crime family.
- A large-scale brawl between the Hells Angels and the Breed in Cleveland on March 6, 1971, led to the deaths of five bikers and twenty-three injuries.
- David Hartlaub was murdered in a bank parking lot near the Musicland record store that he managed on February 27, 1988, by three members of the Hells Angels motorcycle gang.
- The Hells Angels have avoided Oregon since 1967 due to a drug war with the Gypsy Jokers.
- Hells Angels prospect Robert "Bugeye Bob" McClure was convicted of quadruple murder and sentenced to four consecutive life terms in July 1994 for the shootings of Margo Compton, her six-year-old twin daughters, Sylvia and Sandra, and Gary Seslar.
- McClure's alleged accomplice, Benjamin "Psycho" Silva, was never charged in the case due to his existing sentence for a 1981 murder.

- Oregon: Hells Angels (HA) have avoided Oregon since 1967 due to an agreement with Gypsy Jokers. Robert "Bugeye Bob" McClure, a HA prospect, was convicted of quadruple murder in 1994. Odis "Buck" Garrett, HA Vallejo, CA chapter president, ordered the killings in retaliation for Compton's testimony against several HAs in a 1976 SF prostitution trial. HA established a presence in West Philadelphia in 2004 after four high-ranking Pagans members patched over. A HA chapter was formed in West Philadelphia in 2004. A HA member was airlifted to Cooper University Hospital after being assaulted by Pagans in 2005, leading to the Angels' New York-based East Coast leader declaring war on the Philadelphia Pagans chapter. Wood, the Philadelphia HAMC vice-president, was shot dead in 2005. The Philadelphia Hells Angels chapter was disbanded in November 2005 due to poor leadership.

- Pennsylvania: An alliance between the Pagans and the Philadelphia crime family has historically prevented the Hells Angels from establishing a presence in the Philadelphia area. In 2002, a South Philadelphia tattoo parlor owned by a Pagans member was firebombed, a Sons of Satan clubhouse was destroyed by a pipe bomb explosion, and a HA chapter was formed in West Philadelphia. In 2005, Pagans members allegedly stole a sign from the HA clubhouse, resulting in an exchange of gunfire. The Philadelphia Hells Angels chapter was disbanded in November 2005.

- Rhode Island: The Hells Angels' Rhode Island chapter was formed in Providence on September 5, 1992. The Hells Angels have established a working relationship with the Providence faction of the Patriarca crime family, acting as enforcers for the Mafia. Christian A. Rufino, a member of the New Rochelle, New York ("New Roc City") chapter of the Hells Angels, was sentenced to fifteen years in prison after being convicted on a federal firearms charge in April 2012.

- Philadelphia Hells Angels chapter disbanded in 2005 due to poor leadership and a failed war against the Pagans.
- Rhode Island chapter established in Providence in 1992 and has worked with the Providence faction of the Patriarca crime family.
- Christian A. Rufino, a member of the New Rochelle, New York chapter, sentenced to 15 years in prison for federal firearms charge in 2012.
- Douglas Leedham, a member of the Rhode Island chapter, sentenced to 7 years in prison in 2019 for trafficking methamphetamine, cocaine, and being a felon in possession of a firearm.
- The Hells Angels' first chapter in the Southern States was established in Charleston, South Carolina on February 7, 1976.
- Artie Ray Cherry, a founding member of the Charleston chapter, died from a gunshot wound in 1982 during a bar brawl.
- Fred Martin Scarnechia, the president of the Hells Angels' Charlotte, North Carolina chapter, and another club member, Thomas Lee Campbell, assaulted a DEA agent in 1982.
- Sixteen members and associates of the Hells Angels' South Carolina Nomads chapter were convicted of crimes related to the RICO Act in 2013.
- The group engaged in drug dealing, money laundering, firearms trafficking, violent crimes, attempted armed robbery, arson, and other offenses.
- In excess of one hundred guns and various drugs were recovered during the execution of search warrants.
- The Hells Angels' leadership coordinated the criminal activity and received kickbacks from proceeds generated by members and associates of the chapter.

- Hells Angels leadership transition in chapter:
	+ Long-time member "Diamond" Dan Bifield voted out as president, replaced by recent inductee Mark "Lightning" Baker in 2011-2012
- Investigation and arrests:
	+ Law enforcement operation started after Bifield made a drug deal with an informant in 2011
	+ Twenty people (16 men, 4 women) arrested in June 2012
	+ Last of the convicted sentenced in June 2013 to over 100 years imprisonment collectively
- Ambush and wounding of Pagans members:
	+ Four New York metropolitan area Hells Angels members and one prospect convicted
	+ Attack on two southern Virginia-based Pagans members at a motel near Greenville on September 10, 2018
	+ One Pagan shot, other beaten with a hammer
	+ Dominick J. Eadicicco and Anthony Milan pleaded guilty to malicious wounding by a mob and use of a firearm in the commission of a felony, sentenced to 8 years in prison
	+ Nathaniel A. Villaman, Joseph Anthony Paturzo, and Richard E. West pleaded guilty to malicious wounding by a mob, sentenced to 4 years in prison
- Hells Angels in Washington state:
	+ Nomads chapter founded on July 16, 1994
	+ Rodney Lee Rollness, Joshua Binder, and Paul Foster convicted of racketeering offenses in 2001
	+ Rollness and Binder involved in the murder of Michael "Santa" Walsh, who allegedly falsely claimed to be a member of the Hells Angels
	+ Foster aided in the murder and helped cover up the crime, hoping to join the Hells Angels
	+ West Coast leader Richard "Smilin' Rick" Fabel also convicted of racketeering offenses.
